Award.AwardTitle: Gravitational Physics from the Cosmic Microwave Background
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is for the study of gravitational physics and cosmology through measurements of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation. The research has two main components that complement what we expect to find with the Planck satellite and other measurements. In the first component, we continue our support and leadership of the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT). Specifically, working with the ACT team, we will test detectors for, build, deploy, observe with, and analyze data from ACTPol, a new polarization sensitive receiver. The scientific payoff from ACT, measuring the CMB at small angular scales, has been considerable thus far and we expect ACTPol to be as successful if not more so. In the second component, we will observe with, upgrade, and analyze data from the Atacama B-mode Survey (ABS). ABS is aimed at detecting the signature of primordial gravitational waves in the polarization of the CMB at large angular scales.

Measurements of the CMB have revolutionized our understanding of the universe. We now have a standard model of cosmology that is so well tested we may use it as a foundation. The current generation of measurements is aimed at such things as determining the mass sum of neutrinos, elusive sub-atomic particles, and finding primordial gravitation waves. Thus CMB observations are touching on and informing everything from particle physics to quantum gravity. The lure of this exciting science has led to the invention of new types of detectors and detecting systems as well as to new algorithms for analyzing the data. The research is done by undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs who are active participants in international collaborations. These students and postdocs go on not only in astrophysics but in other branches of science and in research labs as well. For example, former students are working at NIST on advanced X-ray detectors, which are intimately related to our detectors, for threat assessment and other applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The cosmic microwave background (CMB) is radiation that comes to us from the furthest reaches of the universe. As such, encoded in it are both the conditions of the infant universe and signatures of the contents of the universe that arise from interactions with the radiation as it traverses the universe on its way to us. The CMB is arguably the most potent cosmological observable.

This award supported scientists at Princeton working on the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT), located at 5200 m in northern Chile. ACT has given us one of the most precise and accurate pictures of the CMB at angular scales that complement those probed by the WMAP and Planck satellites. From the data we have discovered new clusters of galaxies and new phenomena.

One particularly important observation was that of the bending of the CMB radiation as it propagates by massive objects in the universe. This phenomenom, a prediction of Einstein's General Theoryof Relativity, is called "gravitational lensing" and allows us to map out the location of mass concentrations in the universe. ACT was the first experiment to observe the effect and continues to build on this start.

In a separate but unrelated observation, we saw in the CMB for the first time the effects of motions of clusters ofgalaxies. This phenomenom is called the "kinetic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich" effect and was predicted over 40 years ago. Continued observations of it will allow us to study the evolution of cosmic structure formation inthe universe.

The award also supported the Atacama B-mode Search (ABS), an experiment to search for gravitational waves from the birth of the universe. LIGO recently detected gravitational waves from inspiraling black holes. It is possible that quantum processes in the early universe also produced gravitational waves. While LIGO detected wavelenghts near a few thousand kilometers in size, the wavelengths of the primordial gravitationalwaves would be stretched by the expansion of the universe to be a few percent the size of the observable universe, a hundred, billion, billion times longer than those seen by LIGO. The effects of the primordial gravitational waves can be seen in the pattern of polarization of the CMB.


Mentoring the next generation of scientists at all levels was a considerable component of the award. The Princeton group runs an active summer program for undergraduates; we originated a Bridge Program and mentored its first student; and we mentor an unusually diverse group of PhD thesis students, over half of whom are women. The group at Princeton was particularly active in the testing and assembly of the arrays of thousands of detectors operating at a tenth of a degree above absolute zero, and in the analysis of data. There are strong ties to NIST and other collaborating institutes around the world.
